Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2013 10:06AM Jinkala wrote: I had long hair but I got it cut up to shoulder level right before my surgery to make it easier to care for with limited mobility.  I never shaved it for chemo and just let it gradually come out.  I think clean up was a bit easier as the hair was long enough to grab the loose stuff in the shower and off of my pillow (main places where it was shedding).  I also kept brushing it every day to get the loose stuff out.  I think I had lost about 60% after the first chemo and was probably up to 98% or so by the time I finished chemo.  I finally just pulled the remaining straggly stuff (most of which was in the back down by my neck) once I realized my hair was growing back just to make it more even. It's still super short and growing slowly.  It's very soft and fine and so far, just as straight as ever.  My last chemo was in November and I'm still probably around a half an inch.  I'm still on Herceptin so I'm hoping it speeds up once I'm done with that.  I'm not taking anything extra to promote growth though.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 12:00PM Jinkala wrote: Adults put things off too out of fear and embarassment.  I was having issues with my one nipple being chapped and sore for about a year before I got it looked at and the only reason I went in was because of a painful cyst under that breast and not because of the nipple problems.  Of course you can't really have them look at one part of the breast without the other so I had to explain my sore looking nipple to the urgent care nurse and she referred me right away to a breast specialist.    Yeah, I felt quite a bit embarassed for not having it looked at sooner and I kick myself a bit because it might not have developed an IDC component if it had been removed sooner but I can't change the past so I just need to focus on what I am doing now to make sure the cancer doesn't come back. The fear is totally understandable.  Once you do know what the lumps are, you will feel a lot better because once you know what the problem is, then you can focus on dealing with the problem.    Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 01:12PM Jinkala wrote: 44D here - my options were lumpectomy, single mastectomy or double. I chose to do the single mastectomy with no recon.  While I wanted to have a fast recovery, I also wanted to avoid rads if possible.   I considered a double to keep my appearance 'balanced' but was worried that I would have more trouble during recovery trying to be careful and baby both arms.  I also decided that I would like keeping my good breast as long as possible. Having recon would definitely have meant a longer recovery plus a lot more surgery including surgery on my good breast to lift it to match the reconstructed one.  They just don't make new breasts to match saggy old ones apparantly.    I looked at pictures of reconstructed ones and felt that it just wasn't worth the trouble involved and that I could get the same look under clothing with a good prosthesis. My prosthesis is on order right now but in the meantime, dealing with a single breast hasn't been too awful.  I swear that some of my back problems have gone away and I haven't noticed any issues with balance (as I had been warned about).  I've been wearing a puffy form in a camisole since surgery but I only wear that outside.  At home I don't mind being single breasted in a t-shirt and my boyfriend doesn't mind it either.  I'm happy with my choice so far because it works for me.
